Find all values of $a$ for which the points $(0,0,0),$ $(1,a,0),$ $(0,1,a),$ and $(a,0,1)$ are coplanar.
inference:
Four points are coplanar if and only if the volume of the parallelepiped determined by them is zero.  The volume of the parallelepiped determined by the vectors $\mathbf{u}$, $\mathbf{v}$, and $\mathbf{w}$ is given by the absolute value of the scalar triple product:
\[|\mathbf{u} \cdot (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{w})|.\]Thus, the volume of the parallelepiped determined by the points $(0,0,0),$ $(1,a,0),$ $(0,1,a),$ and $(a,0,1)$ is
\[\left| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ a \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \right| = \left| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} a \\ -a^2 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix} \right| = |a - a^3|.\]Hence, the points are coplanar if and only if $a - a^3 = 0.$  This factors as $a(1 - a^2) = 0,$ so $a = \boxed{0,1,-1}.$
Final Answer: $\boxed{0,1,-1}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
If the points $(0,0,0),$ $(1,a,0),$ $(0,1,a),$ and $(a,0,1)$ are coplanar, then the parallelepiped generated by the corresponding vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ a \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ a \end{pmatrix},$ and $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ has a volume of 0.  Thus,
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 & a \\ a & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & a & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 0.\]Expanding the determinant, we get
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 & a \\ a & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & a & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= 1 \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ a & 1 \end{vmatrix} + a \begin{vmatrix} a & 1 \\ 0 & a \end{vmatrix} \\
&= 1((1)(1) - (0)(a)) + a((a)(a) - (1)(0)) \\
&= a^3 + 1.
\end{align*}Then $a^3 + 1 = 0,$ so $a = \boxed{-1}.$
